Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Bifurcation Theory, Integrable Systems and the Bispectral Problem
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is to provide support for the participation of US researchers and graduate students in an international conference on "Bifurcation Theory, Integrable Systems and the Bispectral Problem" at Sofia University in Sofia, Bulgaria during May 15-19, 2010.

The conference will stimulate the exchange of ideas between US and foreign mathematicians in the areas of integrable systems, the bispectral problem and bifurcation theory. In each of these three areas mathematicians use similar algebro-geometric, representation theoretic, and analytic methods. By bringing researchers in these three areas together, the conference will create new collaborations and strengthen ongoing collaborations between US and European mathematicians. It will expose a number of young researchers and graduate students from the US to fundamental research by leading mathematicians. Informal sessions will provide ample opportunities for junior researchers and graduate students to interact with experts in the fields. The conference will also provide a valuable opportunity for the US graduate students to exchange ideas and education experience with their European peers. This award is co-funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference on Bifurcation Theory Integrable Systems and the Bispectral Problem, supported by NSF grant DMS-1011709, was held from May 15 to May 19, 2010 at Sofia University (Sofia, Bulgaria). One of the main goals of the conference was to stimulate the interaction between researchers working in the three areas of bifurcation theory, integrable systems, and the bispectral problem. The host institution provided facilities and related local organizing expenses. NSF funding was used to cover travel expenses for US participants. In the allocation of funds, priority was given to graduate students, junior faculty and researchers without other support available.

Intellectual merit:
A number of important and difficult results were obtained in the last 20 years on bifurcations of plane vector fields and in the theory of bispectral differential operators. The latter are naturally treated within the framework of integrable systems of KP, Toda and Calogero--Moser type, but more recently many remarkable connections were found to other areas, such as ideal structure of Weyl algebras, matrix-valued spherical functions, Bethe ansatz, and Cherednik algebras. The main aim of the conference was to stimulate the interactions among researchers in the areas of bifurcation theory, integrable systems, and the bispectral problem, as well as the interactions between US and foreign researchers in these fields. In each of the three areas mathematicians use similar algebro-geometric, representation-theoretic, and analytic methods. Bringing researchers in the three areas together would stimulate new collaborations and allow methods and techniques from one area to bring insight into the other areas.

Broader impacts of the proposed activity:
The conference stimulated immensely the scientific exchange between
United States researchers and mathematicians from Germany, Israel,
Belgium, Bulgaria, Switzerland, Russia and the United Kingdom working in the areas of dynamical systems, bifurcation theory, and mathematical physics. Participants expressed on numerous occasions the great impact of the conference on their own research and international collaborations. There was a number of female participants, and many female participants from the United States were funded by the grant (among whom were 2 graduate students and 1 Assistant Professor). The organizers believe that this was a successful effort in the direction of attracting and retaining more female researchers to the field of the conference. A large number of students and junior researchers participated and benefited from the exposure to lectures and interactions with leading mathematical experts. Nine out the 17 NSF funded participants were graduate students and junior researchers.
